document.docAuthor: Johnston, Nikolas P., Wallman, James F., Szpila, Krzysztof & Pape, Thomas
document.masterDocTitle: Integrative taxonomy reveals remarkable diversity in Australian Protomiltogramma (Diptera: Sarcophagidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Integrative taxonomy reveals remarkable diversity in Australian Protomiltogramma (Diptera: Sarcophagidae)

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Protomiltogramma Townsend, 1916: 154
. Type species:
Protomiltogramma cincta Townsend, 1916
, by original designation.

subSubSection.paragraph: Generic diagnosis. General body shape elongate and fusiform; eyes large, occupying more than 0.75 of the head area in lateral view; vibrissa well developed and longer than distance between vibrissal sockets; thorax with five longitudinal stripes dorsally; lower calypter large and dome-shaped; males usually with backward- and up-curved setae latero-ventrally on abdominal tergite 5.

Remarks. The most recent diagnosis of the genus
Protomiltogramma
by Pape (1996) was based on: “vibrissa well developed and longer than the distance between vibrissal sockets”; “lower calypter large and dome-shaped” and “males with setae latero-ventrally on abdominal sternite 5 curved backwards and upward”. The present study found that the abdominal setae (backward and up-curved setae) were present on the male tergite 5 (as correctly observed by Verves 1979 , 1987 ), not sternite 5, and that these abdominal setae were variable between and within species and sometimes entirely unmodified; as such, this can no longer be considered a fully reliable diagnostic character for the genus.

paragraph.keyLead: 1 Abdomen ground colour entirely orange-brown or with a light orange-brown patch laterally on syntergite 1+2 (T1+2) and tergite (T) 3 ( Figs 6A , 7A , 9A , 10A , 11A , 12A , 13A )........................................................ 2

- Abdomen ground colour entirely black or brown or at most with a brown patch laterally on the majority of T1+2–4 ( Figs 2A , 3A , 4A , 5A , 8A ) ..................................................................................... 3
2 Arista dual-coloured: brown or orange-brown proximally and black on distal 0.2–0.5 ( Figs 9B , 10B, D , 12B , 13B )....... 7
- Arista entirely of one colour: orange, brown or black ( Figs 2B , 3B , 4B , 5B , 6B , 7B , 8B , 11B )........................ 8

3 1st flagellomere mostly entirely black/very dark brown, if orange/light brown then darker laterally ( Figs 5B, F , 8B, F , 11B, F ) ................................................................................................... 4

- 1st flagellomere mostly entirely yellow, if orange/light brown then not darker laterally ( Figs 2G , 3G , 4G , 6F , 7F , 9G , 10G , 12F , 13F )............................................................................................... 5

4 Frontal vitta dark red-brown at height of anterior ocellus, gradually darkening to brown-black at antennal insertion ( Fig. 5D, F ).......................................................................
Protomiltogramma incana
sp. n.

- Frontal vitta orange-brown at height of anterior ocellus, gradually lightening to orange-yellow or yellow at antennal insertion ( Fig. 8D, F ).............................................................
Protomiltogramma nigrisensa
sp. n.

5 1st flagellomere shorter than 2x length of pedicel ( Fig. 4B, G ); scutum with major median stripe greater than or equal to 3x width of minor lateral stripes; body length greater than 10 mm ( Fig. 4A )..............
Protomiltogramma grandis
sp. n.

- 1st flagellomere greater than 2x length of pedicel ( Figs 2B, G , 3B, G ); scutum with major median stripe equal to or slightly wider than width of minor lateral stripes (rarely 2x); body length 10 mm or less ( Figs 2A , 3A )........................ 6

6 Genal dilation with white setae only ( Fig. 3B ); fronto-orbital plate white or silver; arista gradually tapering and shorter than or equal to 1st flagellomere ( Fig. 3D, G )........................................
Protomiltogramma dalbiensis
sp. n.

- Genal dilation with both black and white or just black setae; fronto-orbital plate with dull pale yellow or gold microtomentum ( Fig. 2B, D, G ); arista thickened on basal 0.5 then tapered, longer than 1st flagellomere ( Fig. 2B, D ).........................................................................................
Protomiltogramma cincta Townsend

7 1st flagellomere 3x length of pedicel ( Fig. 9B, G )...........................
Protomiltogramma nigriseta (Baranov)
- 1st flagellomere shorter than or equal to 2.5x length of pedicel (12B, F, 13B, F).................................. 11

8 1st flagellomere brown, with brown microtomentum dorsally; basicosta brown....................................................................................................
Protomiltogramma cinnamea Johnston et al.

- 1st flagellomere yellow or orange, with silver or gold microtomentum dorsally ( Figs 6B, F , 7B, F , 11B, F ); basicosta orange, yellow or white ( Figs 6C , 7C , 9F , 11C ).................................................................... 9

9 T3–5 with dull silver/grey microtomentum covering 80% or more of surface, microtomentum strongly changing with viewing angle, visible dorsally, not visible laterally ( Fig. 6C, E ).............................
Protomiltogramma kapnos
sp. n.

11 Abdomen without a distinct black median stripe, otherwise predominantly black, with lateral patches of red-brown ( Fig. 13C, E ).......................................................................
Protomiltogramma subtilis
sp. n.

- Abdomen with a distinct black median stripe (or dark median triangular spots on each tergite), otherwise predominantly orangered ( Figs 10C, E , 12C, E )............................................................................. 12

12 T3 with a pair of distinct median marginal setae ( Fig12C, E ).........................
Protomiltogramma rubra
sp. n.

- T3 without median marginal setae ( Fig. 10C, E )...............................
Protomiltogramma plebeia Malloch
